description:
Description from the publisher:

You're a duck, in a truck, delivering packages.

Unfortunately ducks aren't very good at doing deliveries.
Crates fall of vehicles and other players can steal your cargo!
Delivery Duck is a strategic family game for 2 - 6 players.

Gameplay centres around picking up and delivering cargo. Depos are placed around a dodecagon shaped board. Each turn a player picks up cards that determine the starting location and destination of cargo. Then they place a terrain tile to help them traverse the board or stop others, before moving their vehicles.

The goal of the game is to earn 10 victory points. Cargo comes in multiple types, each with its own monetary and VP value. Strategy comes in deciding which vehicle to use considering terrain, resources on the board and other players actions. Action cards further modify the gameplay.

User summary
ã‚´ãƒª×å¤¢ä¸­ (Gori x Muchuu) is an abstract 2-player strategy game by æ¥ æœ¬èˆ— (Kusunoki Honpo) that was released at the Game Market 2017 Spring in Odaiba, Tokyo Japan.

As the name suggests, Gori x Muchuu is themed with Gorillas and Bananas. According to the publisher it is inspired by the game Geister.

The game doesn't come in a box. The components are a grid sheet, representing the forest, and gorillas chips, which comes in 2 types: square and triangle, 4 of each.

The textbook only feature Japanese but no knowledge of Japanese is required to play the game.

You win if you either:
- Reach the banana square of your color inside your opponent's zone.
- Capture 5 of your opponent's gorilla chips
You loose if you either:
- Capture 4 or more gorilla chip of your opponent of the same type (triangle or square).
- Get your player chip captured

Publisher summary

This is a playing card game developed for italian band BIZARRO WELT. It is based on their Song "Bizarro-Planet der Affen". A limited amount of decks printed in professional-grade quality was sold on Christmas 2016.

The objective of the game is to draw cards from a pile and avoid cards labeled with an evil, mutant ape by neutralizing them with a "battle" card. If an ape card cannot be neutralized, the player looses. The number of battle cards in the game decreases over time. The last player still standing wins.

Additional action cards can give an individual player and advantage over others, for example:

- The "future zombie" card allows a player to look at and reshuffle the top three cards of the drawing pile.

- The "fight" card allows a player to challenge an other player to a side competition (e.g. arm wrestling, throwing darts, drinking etc.). The winner may then take one of the loosers' cards.

- The "downfall" card moves all "ape" cards in the game to the top of the drawing pile.

The game can be played by two to five players, but is most fun with four or five players.

The beloved king Shapiro has perished in a freak catapult accident, but not before his most suspiciously named and irrefutably trusted adviser, Evil Wizard Mordak, claimed credit for his “murder” and legged it through a hastily conjured portal to the WORLD OF ETERNAL AND UNCARING DARKNESS. Mordak promised the kingdom he’d return in 8 days with semi-phenomenal cosmic powers to take his rightful seat upon Shapiro’s ruined throne! A lofty promise for an amateur Wizard…

Valor & Villainy: Minions of Mordak is a one vs many roleplaying board game for 2-6 players. One of you plays as the comically evil wizard, Mordak, and the rest form a band of Allies called the "Order without Borders", who must halt his path of destruction! The game focuses on a strong and playful theme, capturing the best parts of a classic roleplaying game and boiling it into a one time play session. Every player will appreciate satisfying character progression. Spending Experience Points their team has earned and locating powerful Treasures to make their characters mightier with every passing turn!

Mordak has vanished into the WORLD OF ETERNAL AND UNCARING DARKNESS! This player will have a lot of fun, plotting secrets in the dark and throwing despair into the Allies' plans in order to grow in power. They must hold nothing back, drawing upon all of their cunning and evil genius to win the game for themselves!

The Allies must locate three Ancient Shrines hidden among the land. For each of these Shrines diminishes Mordak's power. Finding them all will reveal his location and commence a final battle for victory. They can explore the map at their own pace, however they will learn they must balance their ambitions with what they can handle! Exploring too quickly will fuel Mordak with threats the game-board has to offer, yet doddling will allow him the time to grow his cosmic powers! Ultimately the winner of the game is the victor of the final showdown between the Allies and their nemesis Mordak! Only the party which is better prepared and utilizes superior tactics will win the day!

Description from the publisher:

Covfefe is about the nightmare scenario of 21st Century Supervillains that take over countries from the people through a mix of technology, misinformation, and outright deception. Players are sociopathic dictators trying to dismantle the world to profit themselves and their friends, all the while trying to keep one step ahead of government investigations. The winner is the one with the most Hubris when the world is hobbled by Nuclear War, Economic Depression, or Tribalism.

All players are recently-elected populist politicians who only won their elections through corruption related to an evil empire that is hellbent on world domination. Through manipulation of the public, pointless but politically popular actions, and bald-faced lies, the players try to destroy their governments, making money from evil corporations, and stay one step ahead of government regulations and/or unpopular opinion.

The game has worker placement (we call it ‘scapegoating,’ as your worker may not come back) and worker-developing (like deck-building for workers), multi-purpose cards, and a lot of deception. Welcome to 21st Century politics!

Description from the publisher:

The players in the game run the last bastions of human control, corporations. Governments long ago failed after being dismantled by Emperor Trump. In A.I., corporations are trying to continue to line their pockets with the use of technology, except the technology is starting to work against that. Players are trying to profit handily while staying one step ahead of the A.I., which is starting to think of humans as a virus in the physical world.

A.I.’s key mechanism is the idea of an engine-building game with a potentially intelligent engine. In most engine-building games, players assemble an engine through the acquisition and management of resources to construct from a selection of parts. At some point in the game, the engine that will be run for the sole purpose of making victory points. The interesting decisions in these games is when to make that shift.
 In A.I., the engines have a chance to become sentient and could actually become part of a dummy player in the game that both hinders the ability of the player to progress and competes against all players to possibly win the game.

A quiz game in which players know the category and then have to bet with their cards (2 sets of 1-4 per player). The players betting the highest cards are playing the current round and trying to answer first to win the point. The questions are usually hints that are read by a non-participating player slowly, so people competing for the question can answer as soon as they think to know the answer.
The game is played in 3 rounds of 8 questions each. In round 2 and 3 the players not in the lead may steal a question once each if they are faster than the active player(s).

TopATop Family is a family party game for 3-6 players, aged 4 and above. The gameplay time depends on the number of players and takes between 15 and 30 minutes. It is a simple and very dynamic game in which you will have a chance to use your dexterity, observation and quickness.

During the game, you take turns placing cards in the middle of the table and reacting appropriately to the pictures on the cards played. A player who does that better — either quicker, more accurately, or without making a mistake — than others wins that challenge and collects that card.

A dark curse has fallen over the Kingdom of Sugarplum, and the Frosted Throne sits empty.  As a Dream Mage with incredible powers and powerful ambitions you must set out on a journey across the four realms to take the crown for yourself.

But it will not be easy.

Enemies and Encounters will test you along the Candy Road, dangerous Nightmares haunt your quest, other Dream Mages will do their best to sabotage your endeavor, and even if you do take the crown for yourself, you will have to fight to keep it.

Sugarplum Chronicles is a candy-themed adventure game in which the first goal is to make it to the Crown Tile before any other players.  The second, and final, goal is to be the last surviving Player.  During their turn, players will first roll to move, and decide which direction they want to move in and whether or not they want to stop at Candy Shops or Landmarks along the way.  Depending on the color of the tile that Players land on, they will either face an enemy or encounter (red), draw a nightmare or dream card (black), receive a Lemon Drop treasure (yellow), explore a Landmark (purple), or have a rest (green).

The first Player to reach the crown tile will then hunt down the other players and face off in D-20 based combat featuring edible weapons and items.

Sugarplum Chronicles includes over 45 unique enemies, 'edible' weapons and items, an exciting PVP endgame, and player interaction through spells, mercenaries, magic teddy bears, and more.

In Supérieur: Des Teufels Gebetbuch, designed by author Markus Heitz, who wrote the mystery thriller Des Teufels Gebetbuch (The Devil's Prayer Book), players must adopt their best poker manner to play this bluffing game in which players have a and of only a single card. Each round, they must decide whether to leave, stay, or perhaps even raise the stakes. In the end, whoever has the highest card takes the pot — as long as they don't draw the card of death, which eliminates them from the round immediately.

Description from the publisher:

The shadow of Bhaal has come over Baldur's Gate, summoning monsters and other horrors from the darkness!

As you build and explore the iconic city's dark alleys and deadly catacombs, you must work with your fellow adventurers to survive the terrors ahead. That is, until some horrific evil turns one — or possibly more — of you against each other. Was it a mind flayer's psionic blast or the whisperings of a deranged ghost that caused your allies to turn traitor? You have no choice but to keep your enemies close!

Based on the award-winning Betrayal at House on the Hill board game, in Betrayal at Baldur's Gate you'll return to Baldur's Gate again and again thanks to the fifty included scenarios only to discover it's never the same game twice.

Can you and your party survive the madness, or will you succumb to the mayhem and split (or slaughter!) the party?



Of the 50 scenarios, some end up being purely cooperative, with all the players winning or losing together. But the normal mode is that it becomes one-vs-many.

A card and board game for 2-6 players in which each player takes the role of a Demon Hunter.

The game board depicts Europe in the late 1800s. 20 cities are marked on the board, with each city connected to 1-4 other nearby cities.  Some cities may have an effect on die rolls or creature capabilities.

There are 3 decks: 
-   The Character Deck represents advantageous traits that the characters start the game with.
The Research Deck comprises cards aid that aid the Demon Hunters in their quest. Players acquire these during play. Card types include: Events, Spells, Weapons, Armour, Items, and Companions. 
-   The Creature Deck need to be small to fit easily on the map and represent the creatures that can be found in the various cities. Creatures have a strength and a victory point score (earned by defeating them)

Each player starts with 5 Hits. Each player draws and keeps 5 character cards.  Each player rolls 1D20 to determine their starting City. 
Randomly distribute the X top cards of the creature deck to random cities, where X = the number of players. (Max Monsters in any one city at start is 2)

Players take turns with each turn having 4 Phases:

1.  Destiny Phase
-   The current player draws the top research card from the deck and places it in his hand.

2.  Evil Phase
-   For each player roll 1D6: on a roll of 4+ flip over the top card of the creature deck and for each new creature roll 1D20.  Place the creature on the indicated City.

3.  Action Phase
-   The Current player may take 2 actions. There are 6 possible actions: 
1.  Rest Action - Roll on a healing table to heal any hit points lost.
2.  Travel Action – Roll on a movement table to move 0-2 spaces.
3.  Search Action – Roll on a search table to determine whether you can find a creature to fight.
4.  Recruit Action - Put one Weapon, Item, Armour, or Companion card into play. A character can only have a maximum of 1 armour card, 2 weapon cards and 2 companion cards in Play
5.  Research Action - Roll on a research table and draw 0-3 research cards from the deck and put them in your hand. (You may do a max of 1 research action per turn)
6.  Trade Action - If you are in the same city as 1 or more other Demon Hunters, you may trade resource cards, in hand or in play.

4.  Fate Phase 
-   Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess. 
-   If at the end of a turn, any city has 5 or more creatures, it is 
overrun and all players lose.

When fighting creatures roll 1D20 (The Battle Roll) and add any force bonuses you might have. If this number is equal to or greater than the strength of the creature you defeat it. Place defeated creatures in your victory pile. 
If your modified roll was less, the creature remains in play and roll on the Wound Table taking damage accordingly. If you are reduced to zero Hits skip your next turn and return to play with just 1 hit. 
If after losing a battle roll, you still have hits you may decide to either 
continue the combat or flee. If you decide to continue, make another battle roll against the same creature. If you decide to flee, you may stay in the city or move 1 space.

The game ends at the end of the turn the creature deck has been exhausted. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game is the winner.

Description from the designer:

In Holmes & Watson 1890-1914: Adventures in the London Fog, players will roll dice and take actions so that they may solve the various mysteries of Victorian London. This roll and write adventure takes place all over the map of London, but be careful, Moriarty lurks around every corner.

On your turn, you will draft dice, use the actions of those dice, and navigate your way around the foggy streets to collect the needed evidence to solve the mysteries. If you cant move forward in your investigations, you lose.

Who will be the best investigator? Who will be thwarted by the schemes of Moriarty? Who will best Sherlock in a match of wits?

This game was entered into the 2017 Gencant Roll & Write Design Contest and received and Honorable Mention from the Judges.

We’ve all heard stories of the great heroes and legends that span the worlds of fantasy, raiding dungeons, toppling strongholds, and slaying malicious monsters. We’ve all sat and listened to the tales of evil warlords and sorcerers raising armies and rancorous beasts to do their biddings. Now’s your chance to be the very source of all these stories! Jump behind the seller’s table. Rife through all the alchemical, magical, and sharp bits and goodies that make up the very foundation of the worlds of fantasy! And match them all up with the tricky characters that are willing to buy ‘em for your good ole fashion gold!

Black Market Bonanza is a living card game where Players select their special Seller Character Card and draw their own Seller's Table worth of Contraband Items to sell to Customers for precious gold coin counters. In the Contraband Deck, Players will find unique Contraband Items, some with special abilities, and tricky Sleight Of Hand Cards that be used for your own benefit or at the expense of your opponents! In the Market Deck, Players will draw the coveted Customer Encounters, the fun and random Market Events, or the dreaded Guard Encounter Cards! Beware of being thrown into Lockdown! Can't play the game much if you're stuck in a cell! All things in the Market Deck depend on your Seller's Skill Checks and lucky dice rolls, so be sure to choose your Seller wisely!

Your ultimate goal is to be the first Player to get to 10 Gold! So get those coins clanking into stacks, get all your items sold, and be the first to take control in Black Market Bonanza!

This board wargame is created to commemorate the forgotten heroes who devoted their lives to defend Hong Kong from the Japanese invasion in December 1941.

Glory Recalled: Hong Kong 1941 it's an Operational level board wargame for 2 players. One player plays as Major General Takeo Ito, the commander of the Japanese 38th Division while the other player plays as Major General Christopher Maltby, the overall commander in Hong Kong.

The game uses a card-driven system. Players take turns to play cards to move their units on map & use cards to add strength in combat. Game units are company-size and one turn represents one day.

The Japanese 38th Division is strong. The Allied player must use their weaker force to delay the invasion as long as possible while keeping casualty to minimal.

Finansije za kasnije ("Finance for Old Days") is a game about different financial products and how to use them. Players start with a birth and childhood, after that they have to decide would they work or study. On the half of the game they form family, and at last work for better carrier. They have different financial products, cash credits, home credits, savings, private pension fund and etc. Goal is to collect as much money for retirement. 
Game is not for sale, but for education purpose, my firm is arranging turners around the country in middle schools to teach pupils how to save money.

Designer Inc's latest video game title Black Souls has achieved international success! Hailed as one of the toughest digital games ever, it has attracted millions of hardcore gamers. The secret behind this huge success lies not in just making an extremely difficult game. Anyone can do that. The true challenge lies in balancing it to be as difficult as possible, but still fair enough that the very best players can survive to the end. Alas, the game studio is heavily short staffed and the management is looking to hire one more Game Designer for developing more content in Black Souls.

You have been given a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to be hired by Designer Inc as a level designer, an integral part of Black Souls' development team! As one of the finalist candidates, you must prove your designing skills under the judging eyes of your future employers in an 'Early Beta Access' trial to create a level that best reflects the spirit of Black Souls - a very difficult, yet fair game. A group of seasoned playtesters will be sent to try out your carefully designed level, and provide feedback on whether they like or dislike it at the end of the run. If the level is too easy, they would not feel challenged at all. If it is too hard, they would all be killed and find it unfair. Who will be the final candidate to be inducted into the ranks of Designer Inc?

This is a uniquely themed game - A game about designing a game!

How To Play:

All players begin the game with the same mix of party, randomly generated from a deck of Party Cards. The game is split into two phases - The Design phase, followed by the Gameplay phase.

Place all tiles (also known as Assets) into the drawbag, then randomly take out an amount of Assets equal to the number of players and place them in the middle of the play area. This will be known as the Asset Pool. (Minimum Assets drawn from bag is 3, even if it is only 2 players)

Players then secretly select one of their 6 Bid Cards (valued 1 - 6) and reveal them at the same time. In descending order with highest bid value first, players take turns to pick an Asset from the Pool. Players must immediately place their newly acquired Assets onto their own individual player boards. They can choose to place the Asset on any of the 3 available levels. When placing on levels 1 and 3, the Asset must be placed in the leftmost empty space of that level. If the player decides to put it on level 2, the Asset must be placed in the rightmost empty space of that level.

On each Bid Card, there is also a secondary effect that will occur. Much of the game's strategies revolve around cleverly using these effects at the right time. The value 1 card allows a player to place a Tavern on the newly acquired Asset, while the value 2 card allows a player to immediately add 1 party member with the type based on a card draw from the Party deck. Value 3 allows one to take back all his previously played Bid Cards, including that card itself. When value 3 is played, all other players must place their newly acquired Asset face-down! Value 4 allows one to add one more Asset from the drawbag to the Pool when it is his turn to pick, and value 5 allows one to swap the positions of two previously placed Assets. Value 6 allows a player to place a Shrine on the newly acquired Asset. On a tie (more than 1 player playing the same value Bid Card), both players go last! (Even if they both played a 6) On top of that, their Bid Cards' secondary effects do not trigger too! Value 3's secondary ability will always trigger, even if tied.

All players do have a Hack skill they can each use twice per game, which allows them to avoid losing the effect of secondary abilities during ties as well as keeping their bid numbers instead of going last. Between the tied players, the play order follows the previous turn. If player A and B tied, and player B had her turn before A in the previous turn, she will continue to have her turn before A in this new turn. If players tie in the first turn of the game, the play order ascends from the youngest first.

It is important to note that Assets belong to three types - Cave, Dungeon, and Outdoor. Players will gain bonus points if they can chain and connect more Assets of the same type together.

After 12 turns of Design phase, all players' boards should be filled completely with 12 Assets each. The Gameplay phase will then begin. This is when all players' parties start from their leftmost Asset on the first level, and work their way forward until the last Asset on the rightmost space of level 3. All Assets in the game have 4 values - The first value shows how many fighters will die in that Asset, the second shows how many mages will die, the third shows how many healers will die and the fourth shows a rating of how difficult the Asset is. Players choose to resolve only ONE of the first three values.  Clever decision making is important to minimize death across the various classes in each party.

To win the game, you must ensure that your party survives throughout the entire level to the very end (yes, the same level you designed earlier) Then you will gain bonus points for your dungeon's difficulty, as well as for every 3 dead members. Hence, the best players are the ones who can design very difficult levels but still get their party to the end. It is VERY common for entire parties to be completely wiped out though - afterall, this is Black Souls!

Description from the publisher:

Dusk is falling. Wind is howling. Will you survive the night? It’s possible, if only you can make it to the Safe House. Grab your friends and dash across the neighborhood. Duck in and out of rundown houses, hiding as best as you can. The house at the end of the street is almost in sight. You can make it, just keep running. You can make it. Just. Keep. Running.

In Safe House, players are attempting to cooperatively save survivors. It’s a real time game that demands good teamwork and great communication. It’s frantic fun for all participants.

Description from the publisher:

An open world, adventure, strategy game based in the World of Veles. 2,400 years worth of history that can be discovered through gameplay and in more detail on our website. After the battle of the Iron Gates against the Dark Mages, peace existed in our lands. But then Agrimor, a fire breathing dragon entered Lirennor and killed our king. The king's brother, an evil mage, tried to take power but he failed. He now seeks the Medallion Pieces from the heroes to seize the throne. But the heroes each require what Saladar, the kings brother has. Only one can be crowned the new ruler of Lirennor.

1-7 players with competitive, solo and Co-Op modes to play. Three ways of winning as well as the ability to simply roam around killing creatures, completing side quests and interacting with the game in the open world setting.

Select your base character and build them up as you go along by collecting, buying and winning weapons, items, equipment and so on. Equip these items and become more powerful.

Use magical scrolls to manipulate the map itself. Twist the large hexagonal tiles around. Teleport across the land, conjure weapons, summon creatures, mitigate your opponents' attacks, enchant your items and so on. There are 150 scrolls in the game, so there's always something to do.

The Box itself has been designed with fluidity in mind. Everything is organized as soon as you open the box. There are 500+ cards in the game all within their own tuck boxes. When playing players will use the awesome card trays designed to manage your inventory as you progress through the game and containing your cards to an easy to visualize battle board. And by far the most unique of all the features is the mechanical market located within the lid itself. Future expansion packs are already in mind and the box has already taken care of that. We have included extra room to store whatever is needed now and in the future.

Dead Throne is a game that is never the same. With 10 large double-sided tiles, multiple paths to victory, loads of options and decisions with every turn, and an in-depth world to discover, you'll never say it's predictable.

Just like kittens clawing and wrestling for supremacy, Kitten Klash puts two players in a frenzied dash to grab the most matched cards from a constantly changing tableau. You need the attention of a tiger and the speed of a cheetah to win this lightning-fast real-time game.

In more detail, players continuously lay out cards in two rows of three opposing stacks, keeping an eye peeled for horizontal or vertical color matches. When you spot one, you reach out fast-fast-fast to grab both stacks, then go back to laying out cards until you spot the next match. When one player is out of cards, the round ends and players count up their points from the cards they grabbed: 1 point for each of your own cards and 2 points for each of your opponent's cards.

You can play a round of Kitten Klash in 30 seconds. Play three rounds to see who is the top kitten in your house!

Note: With two decks of Kitten Klash, four players can play as two side-by-side teams frantically seeking and grabbing card matches across six opposing stacks.

It is the Sengoku period, an era of great unrest within the gravely compromised empire of feudal Japan. Your emperor is nothing but a figurehead while the shogun holds the true power. There are many men who desire to hold the title of shogun and then there is you...

Bushido Breaker is a hidden movement card game of deduction & calculated risks, themed as ninja vs. samurai, that is 2-4 players.

The game revolves around the ninja trying to move location-to-location, either disarming enough alarms before assassinating the shogun or by killing all the samurai, in order to win.
The samurai are trying to kill the ninja or notice them enough in order to catch them.

The cards either represent different locations, ninja & samurai actions, or samurai. Every card that the ninja has as an action, the samurai has a counter to. Through deduction, each team is trying to figure out what the other will play round-to-round. Though the samurai greatly out-number the ninja, their greatest challenge is figuring out where the ninja are and what they'll do next...

Grab a plastic bottle (bottle not included. Additional purchase required) and start flipping with the Flip Challenge game! The game rules are simple – ace the Flip Challenges to earn points. First player to 10 points wins! Kids can practice the 34-included trick shot challenge cards solo or compete with friends! Game includes four different sized round targets and 34 bottle-shaped cards, each showing a challenge for the bottle flip. Challenges are grouped by category: some use the targets, some are physical challenges, and 6 cards challenge players to create their own trick shot. Each player has 5 chances to complete a challenge. So, grab a lucky water bottle, and go for the perfect flip!

A card game for 2-4 players based on survival and accomplishment in the Florida City of St. Augustine.

St. Augustine was founded in 1565 by Pedro Menendez. It is the oldest, continuously inhabited European settlement in North America. For the first 200 years of its existence, it was controlled by Spain. The town itself was always very small and poor, but it held an important strategic position. It helped defend the treasure fleets on their way back to Spain by preventing the English and French from building their own settlements along the Gulf stream.

In this game players actively recruit townsfolk, earn gold, gain military glory, and build structures while being mercilessly subjected to hurricanes, raids, disease, and hostile indians.

Each turn is equal to about a decade. The game ends after 20 turns, at which point, historically, the British take control of the city.

Each Player gets a player mat which is divided up into 7 boxes: Government, Churches, Forts, Population, Gold, Glory and Victory Points. Tokens are placed in the boxes on player mats to keep track of each players score in that category. Each player starts with 7 population, 5 gold, and 3 glory.

There are 2 Common Decks: 
1.  The Event Deck - one random event occurs each turn. 
2.  The Action Deck which comprises four suits:
-   Economic (Types: Industry, Agriculture, Trade)
-   Military (Types: Fight the French, Fight the English, Control) 
-   Population (Types: Indians, Blacks, Europeans)
-   Buildings (Types: Government, Churches, Forts)
Each suit has 3 types of card with 4 cards for each type. In addition the deck has 4 leader (wild) cards.

Each turn is divided into 7 Phases:

1.  Draw Phase
-   Each Player fills their hand to 10 action cards.

2.  Trade Phase
-   Players may trade action cards with each other and may also trade tokens on their player mats.

3.  Meld Phase
-   Players may make melds. A meld consists of 1-4 cards of the same type. One card in a meld may be a leader. One card in a meld earns 1 token. Two cards in a meld earns 3 tokens. Three cards in a meld earns 6 tokens. Four cards in a meld earns 10 tokens. 
-   You can make a max of 4 melds, one from each suit. 
-   Tokens earned go into the relevant box on the player’s mat. (e.g. tokens from a population meld go into the population box, tokens from a military meld go into the glory box).

4.  Building Phase
-   Buildings provide bonus resources. Tokens are awarded for having the highest and second highest church, government and fort scores.

5.  Event Phase
 -  Flip over the top card of the event deck. The event is resolved immediately and affects all players.

6.  Score Phase
-   Players gain Victory Points (VP) in based on their population, gold and glory scores.

7.  End Phase
-   Players may discard their action hands down to zero cards.
-   Each player loses one half his gold rounding down. 
-   Each player loses all his Glory.

The game ends after 20 turns.  The player with the most VP at the end of the game wins.

A4 Quest is an adventure game in which you will face countless monsters while going through consecutive locations. Your goal will be to complete specific tasks or just to stay alive! As its name implies, each quest will fit on one A4 sheet, which can be printed so that you can enjoy the game right away! All you need is to pick your hero, arrange a few d6 dice and you are ready to go! The whole thing does not require cutting, you can play directly on the printed sheet, although feel free to split it so that it can fit in your pocket.

Mobility, the possibility to mix the sets, adventures, rooms, and game time under 10 minutes are the main assets of A4 Quest. You have a break at work? You’re riding on a train? All you need is a bit of space and you can start your adventure and put your opponents to the sword! The whole game has a humorous graphic design and its style resembles a two-dimension platform games known from computers or mobile games.

Manage your dice by assigning them to right adventures. Choose from available actions on the field. But remember, you need to plan a few steps ahead! Arrange food so that you can rest, because if you don’t your hero will bite the dust sooner than you think! Also, remember about your hero’s special skills because they might save you more than once!

No matter their race, origin or desires, everyone has the right to be a child. Be it a knight or a magician, when we lie down to sleep the unconscious thoughts seem to transcend all realities. It is up to us, which is the connection between desire and thought, and the best children to all as persons. There are so many dreams created that are not so much that they have nicknamed our house of Factory of Dreams!

Take control of a mystical character such as Fairy, Unicorn, Gnome or Ente and build the dreams that citizens both crave in thoughts. Each character has a special ability that assists in their production and each citizen's card has a different dream to be built. During a match, it is necessary to send out items and emotions cards on the table according to what each citizen card is demanding.

How about joining that magnificent sword, a little courage, and giving the Warrior the glory of that very successful moment for him to kill the fearless Dragon ... in his dreams, of course! Can you be the best mystic in the game and be the employee of the month in the Factory of Dreams? Come and test your gifts, come and dream of us!

GAME SETUP: Each player stands at one end of the table. Your position is important because it determines whether a Desire card is valid for you or not according to the arrows of the cards. All players choose a character. Shuffle the Wishes deck (6 types) and reveal 16 cards in the center of the table placing four cards per row creating a 4x4 square. Shuffle the deck of Dreams and deal 2 cards to each player. The Dream cards are the template from which the player must form the same configuration with the cards arranged on the table.

GAMEPLAY: Fábrica dos Sonhos is divided into turns and actions. Each player on his turn performs the following mandatory actions:
World Change - You must remove a Wish Card from the table and place it in your hand, then replace that card with another one from the top of the Desire Deck or another one in your hand ( maximum of three cards in the hand). If you exceed the limit, before you pick up a new card, you must discard one of the cards in your hand.
Intercept - Choose between moving Desires Cards on the table or buying a new Dream card. The movement of Desires is simple. The movement points you have are equal to the number of players +1 . You can swap two orthogonally adjacent cards, or two cards diagonally that are on the corners of the 4x4 diagram. You can still rotate a letter anywhere. Each change of position or rotation counts as a point of movement.

GOAL: The objective of the players is to format the cards of the table according to the template of the cards of Dreams in their hands. The winner is the player who can achieve 3 dreams first.

COMPONENTS:
1 Rules Book
4 Character Sheet
20 Dreams Cards
38 Desires Cards

Players take on the roll of the mane six ponies from the animated series and work together to prepare for a confrontation with one of the series villains. If the ponies have made enough progress, they can thwart the villain.

Each turn the players move their ponies around the game board, which is a map of Ponyville and Equestria.  They then attempt to deal with plot issue cards by rolling dice; other ponies can help them by rolling additional dice.  Successfully dealing with the issue cards allows them to advance on their Element track.  When they advance far enough, they will gain their Element of Harmony.

Meanwhile, the villain is plotting.  The villain has a progress track which advances each turn and when new issue cards come into play.  Villain event cards will come into play as the track advances and which will cause problems for the ponies.  Once the villain track reached the final space, the confrontation begins.  Ponies then attempt to defeat the villain with a series of dice rolls.  Their success will depend largely on how many Elements of Harmony they have obtained during the game.

Each of the mane six ponies has her own special ability: Twilight Sparkle can advance Element tracks by doing research, Rarity can collect gems to help her resolve issues, Fluttershy is good with animals, Rainbow Dash's movement is faster than the others, Applejack is good at helping other ponies resolve their issues, and Pinkie Pie can help other ponies avoid setbacks.

Players can play stand-alone games or a campaign game made up of a series of games, with a different villain in each game.  The ponies can gain new abilities and even become alicorns as the campaign continues.

Peppermill's Energy Conservation Game

From Cover:
Q. Is there really an energy crisis?
A. Yes, we are using up our favorite non-renewable fossil fuels at a furious pace, but we can learn how to conserve and use solar energy for most of our energy needs.  That's what this game is all about.

From Instructions:
Energy Crisis is a fast moving, game of chance, strategy, and educational fun.  It will challenge adults and fascinate children.  It's a game the whole family will enjoy.

Game Play:
This is a role and move game where players are trying to insulate their house, convert to solar energy and conserve your energy units.  Use your energy units to pay your bills.  There are various spaces on the board where you buy solar collectors and insulation, collect energy, and pay bills.  Play continues until one player acquires 10 solar collectors or until all other players run out of energy units.

Underlords is a 1-4 player fantasy game where players take on the role of the Underlords, hard done by masters of the dark who only want to make an innocent evil subterranean empire filled with minions and monsters. Alas these tranquil utopias find no peace as pesky adventurers keep turning up at the door trying to steal everything and killing every minion in sight.

In Underlords players use tile placement to build a dungeon full of rooms and caves, into which minions and monsters are placed. Each turn the underlord push their luck by sending monsters out to raid villages, towns or cities to gather plunder which is used to recruit minions and build the dungeon.

Each turn one hero arrives at the dungeon seeking treasure. Depending on how hard the Underlord raided, this could be a plucky peasant or a gristle nemesis of evil. The hero travels through the dungeon in a tower defence fashion being battled on the way by the dungeons defenders.

The game is won by the player who accrues the most magic items from fallen hero's by the end of the game.

This is a Sudanese version of Monopoly.

"With regards from The Modern Bank of Luck
The only agent in Sudan"

It is completely in Arabic, but I've had most of it translated.  The mechanics are the same, however with slightly different rule variations.  Properties focus on Arabic cities in Northern Africa and the Middle East including Khartoum, Aleppo, Benghazi and Baghdad.  You can purchase garages, restrooms or markets.

Description from the rules translated into English:
"The Bank of Luck game is one of the best games that guarantees players a good time and makes people love honest trade in the sale and purchase of cities, garages, restrooms, etc.  It is one of the most famous games played by 2 to 6 players and preferably more than 2 players."

A game of Helios Expanse places you in control of an interstellar civilization, competing for galactic supremacy against its rivals. You colonize habitable planets, research technologies, and build a military with which to wage war. The civilization that colonizes the most planets emerges victorious and rules the galaxy.

Helios Expanse was inspired by a vision to develop a board game that provided a 4X play experience in under sixty minutes, and the play experience was crafted to be as satisfying for the traditional 4X gamer as it is for the casual gamer. This vision drove a specific set of design goals that would serve as the foundation for the game design. First and foremost, the game was created around the goal of being teachable in less than five minutes. This specific goal drove a streamlined decision tree resulting in simple, but tactical player choices turn to turn. An emphasis was placed on player interaction to preserve the game play tension typically associated with a 4X play experience. Ultimately, this combination of foundational design goals (along with a few others) led to an action/movement programming game mechanism that created just the right amount of tension turn-to-turn. At its core, Helios Expanse is a highly interactive game with simple, but tactical decisions and cohesive, working mechanisms.

Would You Rather…? Kinda Clean Party Edition is the game of crazy choices and demented dilemmas! Your goal is to figure out which dilemma the other players would rather do. There are two ways to play: Classic Dilemmas give you two outrageous options to choose from, and Fill-in-the-Blank Dilemmas have missing words that you provide. Once the group has revealed their choice, turn over your previously selected Voting Token to see if you matched. With over 1000 dilemmas to choose, Would You Rather…? Kinda Clean Party Edition is where outrageous choices are all part of the game.

FEATURES
Fill in the blank, you pick the words. Expect the unexpected.
A or B dilemma cards offer two different options to choose from.
Over 1000 dilemmas! Outrageous choices are all part of the game!

Player: 2-4 Players
Time: 10 mins (2 players) 20 mins(3-4 players)
Card deck: 52

SETTING GAME:

Shuffling and sharing cards:
A player shuffles and shares the card. Each player would get 10 cards.

BAITING

Each player selects and place 5 CARDS that would serve as BAITS for the fight. These cards are chosen based on the player's choice on elements such as high number, HUT colour etc).

HOW TO PLAY:

1. At their turns, players try to eliminate other player's BAIT by placing a higher number HUT (with the same colour) on the BAIT to be eliminated.

For instance, if a PLAYER has baits with number 9, 9, 8, 7, 8, an active player (player whose turn it is) who places a card with higher number of the same colour as the BAIT collects the BAIT and other cards on it if BAITS has been HEXED, DEFENDED or INVADED (see below).

HEX:

Players can use their turn to HEX any BAIT (either theirs or another players). They do so by placing ANOTHER HUT COLOUR with the same number as the BAIT to change the colour. This is a very important in the game strategy.

DEFEND:

Players can DEFEND their BAIT by placing another card with HIGHER NUMBER but MUST be the same HUT colour as their BAIT. This is a strategy for defence in the game.

INVADE:

ACTIVE PLAYER can weaken another players BAIT by INVADING. This is done when Active Player place a card with LOWER NUMBER on another player's BAIT but must be the same COLOUR. This makes the BAIT weaker and easier to eliminate at next run by any player.

WHEN GAME ENDS:

The game ends when any player has EXHAUSTED their FIVE BAITS.

HOW TO WIN???

THE PLAYER WITH THE HIGHEST NUMBER OF BAITS AT THE END OF THE GAME WINS.

In situations where there is a TIE, the players FIGHTS and the FIRST to lose a BAIT gets ELIMINATED TILL THEIR IS ONLY ONE PLAYER LEFT.

Hermetica is a two-player strategy game set on a dynamic board in which each player must leverage tactical movement and clever combos to outwit their opponent.

The game is played on a hexagonal grid in which each player takes one side and attempts to move their "adept" piece across the board and into the opponent's base. Along with the adept, each player has access to three unique elemental pieces. Each of these four pieces has their own distinct move set that will provide players with a host of options and combos for capturing enemy pieces while vying for board control.

Thanks to dynamic terrain and control over what pieces will be deployed and when, each game plays differently than the last. Lock down strategic choke points. Restructure obstacles to shut down your opponent or open new paths of your own. Set up devastating combos to take your opponent by surprise. With tons of options available to each player at every turn, the possibilities are endless.

Darjeeling is a town and a municipality in the Indian state of West Bengal. It is located in the Lesser Himalayas and is noted for its tea industry, the spectacular views of Kangchenjunga, the world's third-highest mountain, and the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway. Tea planting in Darjeeling began in 1841 using seeds of the Chinese tea plant (Camellia sinensis); the British government also established tea nurseries, during the period, and the Alubari tea garden was opened by the Kurseong and Darjeeling Tea company in 1856 to be quickly followed by more than 80 Tea Estates.

In A Nice Cup of Tea, players compete to cultivate and harvest their own Tea Estates and assist in the building of the Darjeeling and Himalayan Railway, from Siliguri Town to ‘the summit’ at Ghum. Guided by the placement actions of their laborers, players can also use their harvested tea leaves to make Chai for their thirsty workforce to boost their actions even more! When the railway is completed, the player who has contributed the most to the railway, the building of the towns along the way and the most auspicious Tea gardens will be declared the winner.

A Nice Cup of Tea is a new game in the Snowdonia family.

Also nicknamed 'Fashion Fighters', and based on the popular Gaki no Tsukai series, this card game replicates one of their most famous challenges:  Can five heroes (or more!) transform into their super costumes while not caring to recall which hero they actually are?

You take on the role of 5 "Powered" Ranger style heroes in 5 unique colors: Red Ranger, Blue Ranger, Green Ranger, Gold Ranger, and Pink Ranger.  Yet, you are all careless, and always forget which ones you are. Also, NO table talking is allowed because you are also too proud to call each other to ask.

Your goal is to show up to the battle in a unique Ranger suit, matching no other Ranger's color.  Matching another ranger simply will not do, and you will refuse to fight and just go home.  It's embarrassing.

Basic rules: Players have 5 cards each in their starting hands: one card for each of the 5 costume colors (add more colored cards for more players than 5).  Choose a starting player (a lead Ranger) and everyone secretly picks a color costume to wear and puts that matching color card face down in front of them.  Starting with the leader and going clockwise, you will flip your card face up in front of you and yell "[Insert color you played] RANGER GO!".

If all the colors are different, you fight the threat and save the day.  If not, you take any non matching cards into your hand or discard any colors that matched another player (place the discarded card in front of you, face up, so everyone can see what color you lost).

You refuse to ever experience that humiliation again and throw the costume out.  If the same color card is lost by all players, the game is impossible to win, and you instantly lose.

Lastly, (this can be a variant or base rule, your choice) a Ranger will never show up in the same costume twice in a row, so for the following round you must pick a different color to play (eg., yellow, yellow, blue is not allowed, but yellow, blue, yellow is).  Players need to use deduction and pay attention to what costumes are out of play to come out on top!

Decksistentialism is a social metagame that's played whenever something else is going on: at the bar, game night, conventions, whatever. Cards have triggers on them based around simple things like "someone drops something" or "someone uses their phone to settle an argument" as well as darkly funny existential statements related to that trigger like "You cling to what pieces you can, burdened by the knowledge of that which you can never hold onto." When someone sets off a trigger, they get passed the appropriate card. Players can choose how long to play for, and at the end, whoever has the fewest cards still loses (or wins if we're being pedantic). Tragic hilarity ensues.

Circus Clowns pour out of their tiny clown car to form a small human pyramid — but one fool does not make it into the display, and is smacked in the face with a pie for the entertainment of all. Don't be that fool.

You Fool is a 3-4 player bluffing/negotiation game about making a human pyramid of clowns and trying not to be the only player not in the pyramid. In this highly social game, players secretly look at a movement card and try to direct the active player on how to use that card. Sometimes players will cooperate to make the pyramid together and other times they will straight up lie to secure their position.

Once the top three spaces of the pyramid are formed, the game ends. The player who is not on the pyramid loses the game and, naturally, gets a pie to the face.

SimplyClever.Cards Subtraction 1 combines traditional playing cards with math flash cards. The deck has 52 cards in 4 colours numbered 0-12, and 4 jokers.

Each card is illustrated with a subtraction calculation (e.g. 1-1, 3-2 or 15-3) corresponding to the card value from 0 to 12.

One joker has a table showing which 4 cards match up for each value, in order to check the math when necessary. The remaining 3 jokers have mathematical operators +, - and = so you can make your own calculations using the cards.

Designed to function like a regular deck of cards (including traditional pips for suits and ranks), SimplyClever.Cards  Subtraction 1 allows you to play any regular card game you want to - but with a mathematical twist! Game examples: 500, Casino, Crazy Eights, Go Fish, Hearts, Memory, Old Maid, Slap Jack, Snap, UNO etc.

SimplyClever.Cards Division 1 combines traditional playing cards with math flash cards. The deck has 52 cards in 4 colours numbered 0-12, and 4 jokers.

Each card is illustrated with a division calculation (e.g. 0:1, 3:3 or 48:4) corresponding to the card value from 0 to 12.

One joker has a table showing which 4 cards match up for each value, in order to check the math when necessary. The remaining 3 jokers have mathematical operators +, - and = so you can make your own calculations using the cards.

Designed to function like a regular deck of cards (including traditional pips for suits and ranks), SimplyClever.Cards Division 1 allows you to play any regular card game you want to - but with a mathematical twist! Game examples: 500, Casino, Crazy Eights, Go Fish, Hearts, Memory, Old Maid, Slap Jack, Snap, UNO etc.
A re-themed version of Monopoly meant to evoke a feeling of touring as the band Queen.

Brew Ha Ha is a beer-tasting game ...

Players draw 8 cards, sample a beer, then piece their cards together to create a description of what they taste.

The Brewmaster (judge) of each round gets to wield their almighty power to award 2 points:

1 point for their favorite description of the round
1 point for the description they deem most accurate

OXO is a card game with a wonderful mandala look. You can learn it in 5 minutes and you're ready to play.

In OXO, you have to form palindromes with the cards in your hand and in the table in order to get rid of your wealth counters and reach a new status of wisdom.

OXO is a fast, portable, family game. It comes with 2 different modes and can be player in solitaire.

This is a party card game for 3-7 players (or teams). Players create film reviews, deforming the plot, hiding some elements of it or magnifying other aspects. The goal is to ruin the movies (series or books) you love or love to hate.

Furious Ascent is a cooperative game for 2 to 4 players. The object of the game is for all players to progress as a team through four ascents to reach the mountain summit. If all players are healthy enough to reach the summit, the game is won. If any player becomes too injured to continue on during the game, it will result in an immediate loss.

Teammates play colored rope cards in the proper order to conquer four ascents, with each ascent becoming more difficult than the last. Each of the four camp cards has different requirements on how many rope cards and how many colors can be used to progress to the next camp.

If any player during their turn is unable to play the next card in the sequence, they must draw from the Event Deck. Events can penalize the individual player with various ailments, or the team as a whole with loss of progress in the ascent. If any player obtains too many ailments during the game, the entire team fails, and the game is lost. If all players reach the summit, the game is won!

A two player card game themed on The Butlerian Jihad in the Dune Universe as described by the Prequel Trilogy. After a thousand-year standoff, the War between the Free Human League of Nobles Worlds and the Intelligent Machine controlled Synchronized Worlds escalates.

One player is the Humans. The other player is the Machines. Each player has their own unique deck. Each deck has 6 suits. Each card has a force value and a special ability. Some special abilities require their ability to be activated, other abilities automatically take effect when the card is recruited or as a Free action discarded from the hand or in-play.

Each player starts the game with 3 Empire Tokens.

Each round has 6 Phases.

1.  Initiative Phase 
-   Players roll high on 1D6. High roll is the attacker. Low roll is the defender.

2.  Fate Phase
-   Each player draws 5 cards from the top of his deck.

3.  Strategy Phase
-   Each player may discard up to 2 cards and draw replacements.

4.  Battle Phase
-   Players take turns starting with the attacker. On his turn a player can either Recruit (put a card into play face up in front them), Activate (use the activation ability of a card in play if it has one) or Pass. 
-   If both players Pass, one after the other, the Phase ends. 
-   Once a player passes, he must continue to pass, unless his opponent causes one of his in-play cards to be discarded or eliminated. 
-   Normally, during the round, a player can only recruit a max of one card from each of the six suits. Some cards as their special ability allow you to recruit more than 1 card of a particular suit. 
-   A card can only be activated once per round.

5.  Resolution Phase
-   Add up the modified force values of all the cards in-play. The player with the highest score wins. If tied, players roll high on 1D6 to determine winner. 
-   The winner takes an Empire Token from the loser. 
-   The winner causes one target in-play card of his opponent to be discarded.

6.  End Phase
-   Each player can allow up to 9 of their in-play cards to remain in play. Excess cards must be discarded. 
-   Max hand size is 3 cards. Discard excess cards

The first player to control all 6 Empire Tokens wins the game.

A Civilization type game using dice, map, and record keeping for 2-7 players.

A map of the Mediterranean is divided up into multiple areas (about 20 per player).

Each player has a set of units of a unique colour. There are 2 types of units, Population Tokens(PT) and City Tokens(CT). Each player starts by placing 7 PT onto one empty area on the board.

A pad and pencil is used to keep track of Idea Points, Resource Points, Victory Points, and Advances.

There are 8 Phases:

1.  Leader Phase
-   Roll once on the Great Leader Table. Dependant on result a player will receive population tokens or points (Idea, Resource, Move or Victory)
-   The old Leader dies and a new leader is rolled for each of your turns.

2.  City Phase
-   Roll once on the City Table for each City you control. Dependant on results a player will receive a population token or a point (Idea, Resource, Move or Victory)

3.  Advance Phase
-   Gain 1D6 Idea Points (IP). Idea points are saved from turn to turn. 
-   A player may turn in 5 IP to gain 1 random advance.  This is determined by rolling once on a Research Table. 
-   The second advance you buy in a turn costs 7 IP, the third 9 IP and so on. 
-   Maximum IP you can store is 15. Excess is lost.

4.  Growth Phase
-   Gain 1D6 Population Tokens (PT). These may be placed in any areas a player controls. 
-   Max PT a single area can maintain is 10 (plus 1 city). Excess is lost.

5.  Build Phase
-   Gain 1D6 Resource Points (RP). A player may spend 5 RP and discard 5 PT to build a City in any area he controls. An area may contain only 1 city. 
-   A player may spend 10 RP to gain 1 Wonder of his choice. You cannot build more Wonders than you currently have Cities. 
-   Max RP you can store is 15. Excess is lost.

6.  Disaster Phase
-   A player rolls 1D6. On a roll of 5+ his culture experiences a disaster. 
-   Next a player rolls 1D6 to determine how many Population Tokens he loses. These are taken from any of his areas.  A city may be broken down into 5 PT to take losses. 
-   If you have an Advance that mitigates a disaster you get -2 to the casualty roll.

7.  Clash Phase
-   For each other Civ a player is adjacent to, he may choose either trade or war. 
-   If he chooses trade roll on a Trade Table to determine results
-   If he chooses War, attacker picks 2 adjacent areas, 1 controlled by each player.  Each player rolls 2D6 and adds bonuses from War advances. 
The higher War roll total wins (Defender wins ties). Loser loses all units in the area lost. The winner gains control of the opposing Area by placing 1 PT from off the board onto the newly conquered area.

8.  Migration Phase
-   Roll 1D6 to get that many Move Points (MP). 
-   A player may use 1 MP to move 1 PT to an adjacent area. Sailing and road advances allow PT to move further. 
-   Move points are not saved from turn to turn.

The Game ends when any of the following happens: All areas containing land are occupied; all wonders are built; any one player has 7 or more cities or only 1 player is left (automatic winner).

At end of game add up Victory Points from advances and Iconic Leaders, city rolls + 1 per area you occupy + 5 per Wonder built.  The player with the highest VP score wins.
